0.text:
G'day viewers, my name is Graeme
Stevenson and I'd like to invite

4.text:
you to come on a journey of creativity
and learning and adventure

7.text:
through the series Colour In Your Life.
There's an Artist in every

10.text:
family throughout the world and
lots of times there's an Artist deep

14.text:
down inside all of us as well.
So grab your kids, your brothers,

18.text:
your sisters, your aunties, uncles
and mums and dads, and come and

22.text:
see how some of the best
Artists in Australia do what they do.

52.text:
We're in the beautiful city of Sydney this show to
see an amazing artist so come along and enjoy the

58.text: incredible talent that Sydney has to offer.

62.text:
Well g'day viewers, and welcome 
back to Colour In Your Life.

65.text:
We are at the studio of a young lady 
called Meredith Woolnough.

69.text: Meredith, thank you for being on the show.

72.text:
Great to be here. As you can see in the
 background here,there are some amazing

76.text: I mean, I call them ‘material sculptures’,

78.text: and that’s the way that I would describe them. But Meredith actually

82.text:
works in textiles and itís quite 
extraordinary with what she does

86.text:
with them. Also has a Bachelor's degree
 with first class Honors in Arts,

92.text:
which is pretty cool. So she's 
got letters behind her name by

94.text:
the way, and also you're a
 master of teaching as well?

98.text:
So you're not only talented, 
good looking, but you're smart as well?

103.text:
(Laughing) That's ok. But what 
we're going to do, is we're going to

105.text:
spend the day with Meredith on
 how she actually puts these

108.text:
structures together. And she does
 it on a sewing machine, and uses

112.text:
materials, and thread, and 
actually uses materials that actually

117.text:
dissolve. Can you just describe
 to me how all this goes about?

121.text:
Ok. So the fabric that I work on is this stuff. Obviously,
this is a lot of it. It's a water-soluble fabric.

127.text: It was originally invented by the medical industry.

131.text:
They used it as the bags that they 
would wash the surgical equipment in,

135.text:
so when they had contaminated
 implements, it would go

138.text:
inside these bags, and be sent 
off to be sanitized and then the bags

142.text:
would just dissolve and no one
 would have to touch the waste.

144.text:
Like all good inventions it comes from 
the military or the medical industry.

148.text:
But then obviously this had 
lots of other applications, so

150.text:
now it's been pushed out into the
 textiles world. And it's sold in sewing

156.text:
shops as a basic stabilizer, 
but then I'm using it as basically

160.text:
my base fabric. So I don't embroider onto cloth;
this is my cloth and then it's later removed.

166.text:
It's amazing. And I can see by the influence of a lot of
your work, you're obviously very much into nature,

171.text:
but like me, very much into the 
mathematics of nature as well.

175.text:
Yeah. I don't pretend to be good at maths;
you know, art and maths, water and oil

182.text:
But I think itís naturally intrinsically 
involved in all of us. And obviously

185.text:
itís so big in nature. You know, 
we were talking earlier about

188.text:
the Golden Mean, Fibonacci sequence,
 and they come up in things

191.text:
like the Nautilus without even
 trying, and yeah, that's definitely

196.text:
part of it. I donít even know if itís 
a conscious decision or not.

198.text:
It's wonderful, but you've 
obviously developed You've said

200.text:
that this isn't something that's 
yours, but I think that you've developed

203.text:
this to an extent, I mean, as we go through and we screen
up a lot more of Meredithís work as we go along.

209.text:
I have never seen, when I first saw Meredithís work I just was
absolutely astounded, cause it really is art and sculpture and

217.text:
material and it's difficult to describe.
It doesn't really fit into a genre by any means,

223.text:
it's something that you've 
really come up with yourself.

225.text:
Yeah, it's hard to classify. I think any 
work or artwork that's based in textiles,

230.text:
it's really easy to put 
into that textiles or craft

233.text:
bracket rather than Art, but textiles is a fabulous medium,
itís used in so many things, and I think it's really exciting.

241.text:
And maybe it's exciting because it's not
seen that much in the broader art work.

245.text:
Yes. It's amazing, and as I've said, you dive, you go
swimming, you look at the stuff under the water.

250.text: You know, you've got this absolutely fabulous

253.text:
I mean, if you look around Meredith's studio, there's
little bits and pieces of animals and shells, and sponges.

259.text:
There's stuff everywhere, which is just great.
But we're going to go through the process today.

263.text:
You're going to show us how you do
one of these Really, it's only a small one.

269.text: Mmmhmm, yep. It takes a long time to do.

271.text:
Yeah, and you sort of and as you've said before,
you're fairly limited by the size that you can

275.text:
actually create because 
of the sewing machine too.

278.text:
But a lot of these, as you can see, they're 
quite three dimensional in their aspects.

282.text: And she uses all sorts of things to create these,

286.text:
but lets start from the beginning, and tell us how you
go about actually putting one of these together,

291.text:
and then we're going to go through the
process of how Meredith does this today.

313.text:
Ok, so, to start off, I've got
 my water-soluble fabric.

317.text: It's normally a lot neater rolled than this.

320.text: And where would you buy this from?

321.text:
I buy this in bulk, and so buy tens of meters at a time,
and I also buy a really long length of it.

327.text:
But you can get this
 just from a sewing shop.

331.text:
Generally in smaller, more manageable sizes. 
People use it forlace making and things like that.

337.text:
So, this is just a standard embroidery hoop.
You need a hoop because otherwise it's just going to

338.text: So thatís where it came from.

343.text:
get chewed up by the
 machine when you sew.

345.text:
You need to keep it nice and tight.
So, I stretch this out as best I can.

352.text:
It's like a lightweight interfacing, 
if anyone's familiar with that.

355.text:
And if I feel any sort of spongy
 bits I'll just give it an extra tug.

359.text:
IF you tug too much it will tear. Like, it will tear quite easily.
And if it breaks, well, you'll deal with that when

367.text:
I think you've got enough there just to
sort of go back and do it again.

372.text:
So that's going to be what we can work on.
 So make sure this is not wrinkled or anything like that.

377.text: And I can draw onto this.

378.text: You have to be very careful what you draw with.

380.text:
Some pens will dissolve the fabric because they're
very wet, and you want to draw lightly.

386.text:
But you've got to be careful, cause if you
 do draw onto this, when you dissolve it,

389.text:
it might come across
 onto your work. Experiment.

392.text: Ok. So you've got a tightener there. Do you tighten that up at all?

395.text:
If it needs it. Itís pretty snug. But as if Iím sewing a big piece,
with many sections, the piece will become thicker,

402.text:
cause it's got the embroidery
 on it, and I might need to adjust it.

405.text:
So what type of pen do you use to do this thing?
And who makes it? And whatís it all about?

411.text: I just use a basic artline pen.

413.text:
So, you know, they're pretty good, just a basic felt tip,
because they're not very wet and they're very fine.

419.text:
So I can just very lightly draw on it
and itís not going to soak through too much.

424.text:
As far as your designs are concerned,
 I know you're working off nature,

427.text:
you know, things like Mandelbrot
 fractals, but we wonít go

431.text:
into the mathematics about it. But it is quite fascinating.
But a lot of this is just free hand? Do you do stencils at all?

437.text:
Occasionally I'll sometimes draw up
things so I will draw up big designs.

446.text:
Draw up big designs.
So for example the leaf, I've drawn it first.

449.text: Oh wow look at that. That's fabulous.

451.text:
And plan from there. 
There's my nautilus.

454.text:
So I can sort of figure that out. So, you know, I do sketch things
and I do keep sketchbooks of art ideas and things like that.

462.text:
Another point being as well, how do you get that, if you've got
the stencil, onto this? What do you do to get it on there?

473.text: So you can just trace it straight on.

477.text:
From there, what are we going to draw onto
this one? Have we got one ready?

481.text:
Well, we can draw straight onto this, or Iíve got
one where I have drawn it up already.

485.text:
Just to save time. I've just drawn up a basic coral design.
It probably doesn't look like very much at the moment.

491.text: This is one that I've just sketched up, just to make it easier

494.text:
So this is just using the pen using an artline pen. It's just a
basic coral design that I've just drawn from my head,

502.text:
obviously to fit this space. For today Iím going to be limited by
the shape of my hoop, and help that to influence the design.

517.text:
So, we are going to sew. That's the best way to put it.
And you use different is it polyester threads that you use?

524.text:
And, also, I was quite surprised when you brought this out.
Itís a little bit like a colour chart for thread isnít it?

533.text:
But it's amazing. It's a beautiful chart on its own,
but you can see all the lusters in the threads themselves.

539.text:
Yeah, they're good. Polyester is obviously a very strong fiber,
and you need something that's going to be strong.

544.text:
You also, for longevity, need
something thatís going to be colour

546.text:
fast and not going to degrade
like a natural fiber would over time.

551.text:
Ok. And, the sewing machine. What type of sewing machine
do you use and why are you using that sewing machine?

556.text:
I use a Bernina. Itís basically
 the best brand for your basic

561.text:
home-style machines before
 you move on to industrial machines.

564.text:
All the parts are metal, it lasts a long time, and also,
itís smooth when it sews, which is really important for

571.text: me cause I run the machine very hard and fast.

573.text:
And the one thing that you 
obviously do need to do with this

575.text:
would be to make sure that those 
threads are quite bound together.

578.text:
Yeah, itís really important, because if you could
imagine, I'm not using a base fabric at all.

582.text:
The base fabric is going to disappear.
So if all my stitches arenít linked together, when I

587.text:
dissolve it the whole thing is going to fall apart
and itís just going to turn back into threads.

591.text:
So, you've got to make sure that everything's connected
and there's no holes, and all that sort of stuff.

596.text: So has that actually happened to you before?

598.text:
Occasionally. Or occasionally I'll forget to go back
over a piece and I'll dissolve it and then

603.text:
I'll realize there's a bit that I haven't done or
you know, you learn from your mistakes though.

608.text:
Ok, well, from there we're going to go
You've already sketched one up.

611.text:
Weíll go to the sewing machine
 and actually see how this is done.

624.text:
I've just got it set up. I've actually got
different colours on the top and the bottom.

628.text:
The reason for that is, you know, these are basically
my paints but they only come in one colour.

634.text:
So if I want to have variations I can blend them together
when I sew. So I've got it just set up in a way so that

641.text:
it's just the needle going up and down. It's not on anything
fancy or anything like that. I'm drawing with this machine.

649.text:
So Iíve as we know got it all stretched up.
I always bring my threads up to the top,

654.text:
cause these threads will
 get all knotted if you don't.

658.text:
And do you keep holding those 
threads at all? Or do you let them go?

661.text:
What I'll do is Ií'l just sew a little bit, and then I'll
snip them off. And then they're out of the way.

I'll just start drawing; 
it might get a bit noisy.

724.text: I'll only do a little bit, so you can see.

Well as you can see, Meredith has only
just partially completed this section.

And it's just amazing how she follows the little
red lines and gets all the patterns done.

736.text:
But because of the beauty of TV and that this young lady is

742.text:
because it takes quite a long time to do this, at least a
day or so's work to actually sew that like thatÖ

What she's done for us is that
 she's actually prepared one.

And as you can see, completely 
finished and cut out of the frame itself.

Now, there's a really special technique that
happens now, which I've never seen before

759.text:
and which I think will be quite fascinating,
you get rid of this material don't you?

763.text: Yeah. Itís actually very very easy.

767.text:
Basically I would normally do this under running water,
but so we don't have to shoot in the bathroom,

772.text:
I figured this would be much more TV friendly.
So, it needs to be warm water, so I've just boiled the jug.

780.text:
And I'll just get that quite warm. So, basically,
 it'll be there and then it won't be there.

785.text: So Iíll just put it in a little bit, and you can see

787.text:
straight away it just kind of disappears.
 It turns into like a gooey,gluey substance.

793.text: So Iíll just kind of move this about in here.

798.text:
If I don't wash it out enough, there will be a little bit of residue
fabric there, but I don't want to wash it out completely,

806.text:
because it actually kind of turns into a bit of a
stiffening glue that will give it a bit of shape.

811.text: It's just amazing. It just disappeared that quickly.

815.text:
Yeah, it's just gone. Here one minute, gone the next.
Now as you can see I'm not particularly gentle with them.

820.text:
And now this is quite wet. There's a bit of
colour that has come out, but that's not from the thread,

826.text:
that's from the pen that
 I used to draw it with.

828.text:
So now all I do I just use 
some baking paper, so that I don't

837.text:
make a huge mess of the bench.
 And I'll just lay this down and basically

842.text:
blot off the excess water. So once I'm happy
 with what I've taken off, some pieces I'll let to

852.text:
go really sculptural, and crunch them
 up to give them some extra shape.

857.text:
This piece though, because itís wanting to curl, and I want it
to be quite a defined shape to begin with,

864.text:
And to do that Iíll just double layer my
 paper towel, my greaseproof paper sorry.

871.text:
I'll make sure it's all nice 
and flat, as best I can.

881.text:
This bit's a little bit fiddly if it's a really fine
design it just want this to do its own thing.

888.text: Do you want me to hold that there?

894.text:
It's really annoying once you press something
and then you find that bit that's folded over,

898.text:
and it doesn't like to be
 wet again once it's dissolved.

901.text:
So once that's done,my very high tech 
pressing implement; a big heavy book

908.text:
Yes, very inspirational. I just 
sort of pop that on and press that.

917.text:
Ok, from there, we're going to go
 to the mounting process. Mmmhmm.

920.text:
And you've already got one that's huge.
It's just enormous. It's a beautiful leaf.

925.text:
Yeah. So this is I'm really kind of fascinated with leaves,
and the internal structures of leaves at the moment,

930.text: so I've done a slightly larger one today.

934.text:
And I really quite like this when 
it's floppy, but we need to mount it.

939.text:
So I've just prepared this board. 
It's just fabriano paper stuck to

945.text:
foam core, to give it some stability. And once I figure out
which way I want it, which I could spend hours doing,

953.text:
its just a matter of mounting it on. 
Now when its flat, it kind of loses a lot of its

960.text:
whatever makes it special. So I always 
like to mount them so they

971.text:
I just use standard pins. These are just rustless pins;
rustless so that they're last for a very long time.

979.text:
I need my pliers. I need my thimble. And now, basically
these pins I'm just going to push through at

989.text:
places where I know it's going 
to be needed to be lifted up.

999.text:
So once I'm happy with however 
many I've got, I'll go around and push

1004.text:
each one down so that they're 
flush, and tightly pressed in.

1010.text:
And you've really gotta, I'd say, have quite clean hands cause
they're so refined and everything you do is so precise.

1017.text:
I've found I can't wear nail polish. If I do,
 I'll get colourful little blobs on the paper,

1022.text:
and you've gotta be really 
careful with the paper.

1026.text:
It will pick up every little oil from your hand. So now I need to
basically push them all up again, and I just gentlyÖ

1036.text: Just push Oh look at that!

1038.text: Yeah, and it'll just sort of pop up.

1043.text: How bout that. And there it is, just floating.

1047.text:
Now it's not going to stay there on its own. Eventually, you know,
it'd probably it might sag, so I space them out.

1055.text: And I've just got my little container of

1058.text:
these are just like little glass rods, like beads. So with
these, what I'm going to do is I'm now going to

1066.text:
pull all of these out, and
 unwind that half of the leaf.

1070.text:
I was going to say, you wouldn't do it all, cause it
would just sorta tend to flop wouldn't it?

1074.text:
Yeah. If there are pieces that aren't 
this dense I might do it one at a time.

1078.text:
And then I just sort of go
 along, threading these on to

1084.text:
the pins and then poking them back through in
exactly the same holes that they were in before.

1090.text: So you only wanted it just up that high?

1095.text:
Yeah, with this one I'm going to keep it quite close because it's
so dense. And I really want the pins and the spaces to

1102.text:
not be noticeable. I just want it to look like it's floating, but not
really be aware of it. So I'll do this on one side and then

1110.text:
I'll do it for the rest of it.
 It was attached to itself

1128.text:
Ok, so now I've got all my beads in,
 I'm just going to go and push all these down,

1132.text:
and just with a pair of
 pliers, Iím just going to

1136.text:
carefully bend the pins around, 
so that theyíre not poking out.

1141.text:
And then, once I've bent the pins around I'll just
stick them in place with a little bit of tape.

1148.text:
Yeah, thanks. Means it 
won't stab me, or my framer.

1154.text:
And it just sort of holds everything
 into place then as well doesn't it?

1158.text:
Yeah, it'll hold it all into place, and that takes a little bit of time,
and then after that it's just a process of

1164.text: painting in the pins so that you canít see them.

1167.text: Just push them down. That's amazing.

1171.text:
It'll just sit off just enough that in different kinds of light,
you'll get shadows that get cast,

1179.text:
and I sometimes think the
 shadows are just as important.

There's another one that you've got here as well that I'd
just like to look at, which is the nautilus shell.

And this is just going through, once again another process,
obviously all those pins have been nailed down.

But this one, I really love this. Now describe

shadows that come across this, what Meredith has done is

 initial curve in there as well?

With this piece, I basically 
shaped it around some padding,

to give it more shape and

 little piece I started playing with.

then when I dissolved it

 I'll probably just stitch together to

 But with this one yeah, it had that
